name: Smallest primes p_1 where products m of n consecutive primes p_1..p_n are such that only p_1 < m^(1/n).
mathematica: k = 1; Table[r = Range[0, n - 1]; While[(Set[{p, q, m}, {#[[1]], #[[2]], Times @@ #}]; q < Surd[m, n]) &[Prime[k + r]], k++]; p, {n, 2, 6}]
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(ps = vector(n, k, prime(k))); forprime(p = prime(n+1), , if(ps[2]^n > vecprod(ps), return(ps[1])); ps = concat(vecextract(ps, "^1"), p));} \\ _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 23 2024
author: _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 19 2024

name: a(n) is the smallest product of n consecutive primes p_1..p_k, where only p_1 < m^(1/n).
comment: Proper subset of A120944, since squarefree m is the smallest number in the sequence of numbers that have m as squarefree kernel, and since more than 1 prime is a factor.
formula: a(n) = Product_{k=0..n-1} k + pi(A374873(n)), where pi = A000720.
mathematica: k = 1; Table[r = Range[0, n - 1]; While[(Set[{p, q, m}, {#[[1]], #[[2]], Times @@ #}]; q < Surd[m, n]) &[Prime[k + r]], k++]; m, {n, 2, 6}]
author: _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 20 2024

name: Smallest primes p_1 where products m of n consecutive primes p_1..p_n are such that only p_n > m^(1/n).
mathematica: k = 1; Table[r = Range[0, n - 1]; While[(Set[{p, q, m}, {#[[1]], #[[-2]], Times @@ #}]; q > Surd[m, n]) &[Prime[k + r]], k++]; p, {n, 2, 6}]
program: (PARI) a(n) = {my(ps = vector(n, k, prime(k))); forprime(p = prime(n+1), , if(ps[#ps-1]^n < vecprod(ps), return(ps[1])); ps = concat(vecextract(ps, "^1"), p));} \\ _Amiram Eldar_, Sep 23 2024
author: _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 22 2024
